message: There are a lot of (lightweight) frameworks for Python but I wonder what people use to build websites for their clients?
I tried some of them but I think they might be to complex for my clients. At the moment I use a Asp.Net cms.
I just tried it and it looks okay but it's a step back from the one I am using right now.
Also it looks like it's more of a 'page' based cms instead of a content one.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/184742/what-is-a-good-cms-written-in-python-and-not-plone this is a lost of CMS I got from the other chatroom. Anybody uses any of those?

i don't build many websites anymore, but when I used to it was drupal until recently when django-cms came along and more shared hosts were supporting mod_wsgi. compared to drupal, django-cms used to be a pain in the ass to setup. but it looks like they fixed that. https://www.django-cms.org/en/documentation/
well, drupal or wp out of laziness mostly. Not laziness to do it in anything better, but laziness to explain why they'd need to host on x so we can use y.
I use Django even for simple websites. Possibly overkill in some cases, but it makes the tiny bits of customization that my clients come to desire an easy task.
Flask for small sites, Django for bigger sites, CakePHP if PHP is a must...
@aseba *shudder* It should never be a must..
@michaelschade but when it is, sometimes there isn't anything you can do about it…
Flask would be nice if it came with some CMS module.
Also it's focussed towards blogging
Well WP is okay and the back-end is really pretty but for non savvy clients it's not that great.
The default CMS is always Wordpress. You need to come up with a compelling reason why Wordpress won't work. Scale/customization/ extensive internal experience with python.
Well wordpress is horrible to work with.
@Enome If you think WP is bad, you should see what people come up with on their own. Wordpress is shining beacon of simplicity and ease in a sea of half-baked PHP "frameworks".
Also it uses PHP ^^
Static html is good...
@coderanger Yes, because Wordpress is fully-baked and now crunchy in the middle. ;)
If it's static then I use Jekyll

For a cut & dry website that doesn't need a lot of unusual functionality, there really is no good Python alternative to Wordpress. With the extendability, already created plugins, and ease of use / availability of documentation it is an easy choice.
Biggest downside, imo, (besides being PHP) is that because it's so popular it's a big target for attacks.
Didn't know Wordpress was so popular for real websites. Thought people would prefer something that's less focussed on blogging.

@Enome: That used to be the case, but they've really made it easy to use it as a CMS with less focus on blogging. Especially now with custom post types you can do quite a bit outside of the normal with it.
One idea is to use sphinx ( I know its purpose is for documentation ).  You can customize it.
@davidwparker, you can use hyde, it's pythonic
@davidwparker Have you customized hyde? How are its internals?
@justinlilly I haven't customized hyde, @myfreeweb just recommended it to me. To be honest, I use both Ruby and Python regularly and don't have qualms about going either direction.
I often say Django is a very good CMS framework (but not the best application framework)
Sphinx is also nice for the more simple cases
@dag What do you consider the best application framework?
Perhaps Pyramid and Flask
web2py
We have built http://radbox.me on web2py
Pelican is much simpler than Hyde and it's getting better everyday :) http://docs.notmyidea.org/alexis/pelican/
Wow , Pelican is awesome.  Better that toto, because is ReST and also has pygments support.
An example ( spanish ) of a blog created with Pelican, and host in Amazon's S3 http://jdacpelican.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/
Pelican *is* awesome. I wrote a wordpress importer for it in a few hours. Dead simple. I hope to migrate to it soon.
Just trying out Blogofile Static generator pretty full featured has blogger and Wp importers, Disqus comments and lots of other goodness, write html, markdown. RST has Pygments built in
@Enome Something like Padrino built on top of Flask would be cool
@sooyoung That's actually pretty cool.
Django CMS is fantastic for small business sites.
